source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_040_chunk1
evidence_span: In out-of-pile corrosion tests in water at 300°C, nodular corrosion originates in zirconium alloys containing only transition elements (iron, chromium, and vanadium) but not tin after extended exposure times (several hundred days).

evidence_span: At short exposure times, materials with large precipitate sizes $( > 0 . 1 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } )$ generally have thicker oxide layers than materials with fine precipitates.

evidence_span: Figure 3 shows the oxidation behavior of certain lots in different BWRs and reveals that both the corrosion rate as well as the time dependency can vary in different BWRs for the same material.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_040_chunk2
evidence_span: Highly reliable data can be derived from experimental fuel elements, where the claddings of the different fuel rods have been varied with respect to material condition and chemical composition after an exposure of more than 1000 effective full power days (EFPD) corresponding to a burnup of more than 30 MWd/kg.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_040_chunk2
evidence_span: The WTRs were exposed up to four cycles to an equivalent burnup of 30.2 MWd/kg.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_040_chunk2
evidence_span: Measurements of the weight gain of the individual samples were performed after one, two, and four cycles in hot cells.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_040_chunk2
evidence_span: Material coupons with a high tendency to nodular corrosion showed nodular corrosion on the whole surface and high weight gains, material coupons with a medium sensitivity to nodular corrosion revealed white oxide only around the holes for the stainless steel pins and low to medium weight gain, whereas samples with a low corrosion sensitivity showed only uniform black oxide and moderate weight gain.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_040_chunk2
evidence_span: The typical appearance of samples with different corrosion sensitivities after an exposure time of two cycles is shown in Fig. 5.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_040_chunk2
evidence_span: The size of the precipitates was determined as the geometrical mean from high-magnification $( > 4 0 . 0 0 0 )$ transmission electron microscopy.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_040_chunk2
evidence_span: At short exposure times (one and two cycles), all materials with precipitate sizes up to $0 . 1 2 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ exhibit low corrosion, whereas those with larger precipitate size show increasing corrosion with increasing precipitate size.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_040_chunk2
evidence_span: At long exposure times (three and four cycles), increased corrosion is not only seen for materials with large precipitates but also in materials with extreme fine precipitates. Lowest corrosion is now observed for materials with a medium precipitate size (0.075 to $0 . 1 2 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ .

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_040_chunk2
evidence_span: This precipitate size can be achieved by a fabrication routine that leads to an accumulated annealing parameter of $2 \cdot 1 0 ^ { - 1 9 }$ to $1 . 5 \cdot 1 0 ^ { \cdot 1 8 } \mathrm { ~ h ~ }$ (for $Q / R = 4 0 0 0 0 \ \mathrm { K } )$ .

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_040_chunk3
evidence_span: the weight gains measured on corrosion coupons exposed in a WTR at the same axial position for four cycles is shown versus the tin content of these samples. The figure indicates that nodular corrosion increases significantly with decreasing tin content below the ASTM range for Zircaloy-2 and -4 and less pronounced within the ASTM range.
